title: Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve Injury After Thyroidectomy
setup_script: You are notified on postoperative day 1 that your thyroidectomy patient is hoarse and stridorous. She had a total thyroidectomy for multinodular goiter yesterday. Her calcium is normal. No drain output abnormalities.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Assess airway patency and signs of respiratory distress; call anesthesiology for possible re-intubation.
Perform bedside laryngoscopy to evaluate vocal cord function; identify unilateral or bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
If bilateral nerve injury causing airway obstruction, emergently secure airway with tracheostomy or re-intubation.
For unilateral nerve injury, counsel patient about voice changes and plan for voice therapy; monitor for aspiration.
Review operative note for difficulty with nerve identification, risk factors like large goiter or reoperative surgery.
Order neck ultrasound to rule out hematoma or seroma compressing airway; if present, evacuate immediately.
Ensure calcium levels are stable and look for signs of hypocalcemia causing laryngeal spasms.
Consult ENT for laryngeal EMG and evaluation of vocal cord mobility.
Discuss potential for nerve recovery (up to 6-12 months) and plan follow-up with speech therapy.
Document complication disclosure with patient and family and inform risk management.
Review your surgical technique to identify possible improvements for nerve preservation.
Arrange postoperative follow-up to assess voice function and consider medialization procedures if no recovery.

critical_decision_points: Prompt recognition of airway compromise and securing airway if bilateral nerve injury.
Evaluation for compressive hematoma causing stridor.
Counseling patient on prognosis of nerve injury and need for therapy.
Involving ENT and speech therapy early.
